byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT and THOM SHANKER

abstract: Obama administration considered using cyberwarfare to disable air defenses of Libyan leader Col Muammar el-Qaddafi in March 2011, but ultimately decided to use conventional airstrikes instead; rejected employing cyberattacks for fear that it might set precedent for other nations to carry out such offensives of their own.
snippet: Obama administration officials decided to use airstrikes to disrupt and disable the Qaddafi government in March, but only after a new kind of warfare was discussed.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

lead_paragraph: Obama administration officials decided to use airstrikes to disrupt and disable the Qaddafi government in March, but only after a new kind of warfare was discussed.

headline.main: U.S. Debated Cyberwarfare in Attack Plan on Libya
headline.print_headline: U.S. Weighed Use Of Cyberattacks To Weaken Libya
